sn11.8:1.1.comm: Chāndogya Upaniṣad 8.7–12 tells of how Virocana studies with Indra under their Progenitor, Prajāpati, to learn about the higher Self that is free from evil and death. The Sutta responds to that dialogue, drawing its key vocabulary and ideas from the Upaniṣad and setting them to a quite different purpose (cf. SN 3.8). A number of interpretive difficulties can be resolved in this light, resulting in a more satisfying text.

sn11.8:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā divāvihāragato hoti paṭisallīno.
sn11.8:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Buddha had gone into retreat for the day’s meditation.

sn11.8:1.3.pli: Atha kho sakko ca devānamindo verocano ca asurindo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā paccekaṃ dvārabāhaṃ nissāya aṭṭhaṃsu.
sn11.8:1.3.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, and Verocana, lord of titans, approached the Buddha and stationed themselves one by each door-post.
sn11.8:1.3.comm: Verocana is “son of Virocana” (Agni or the Sun). He is called Bali at DN 20:12.9. His story, detailed in various legends of later times, tells how he was a great king of the titans who at times even defeated the gods and ruled heaven, but did so justly. Here he seems to have settled his long enmity with Indra. In the Sutta, he may as well be Virocana himself, as Pali is not always assiduous in maintaining patronymics.

sn11.8:1.4.pli: Atha kho verocano asurindo bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn11.8:1.4.eng: Then Verocana spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn11.8:2.1.comm: The Upaniṣad says the “highest man” (uttamapuruṣa) is the one who rises up from his body and manifests in his own form as the perfect light (8.12.3). | The theme of effort is implicit when the Upaniṣad urges that that the Self “should be discovered, should be cognized” (so ’nveṣṭavyaḥ sa vijijñāsitavyaḥ). It is hidden from normal perception and requires a long spiritual training.

sn11.8:2.2.comm: The Sutta substitutes attha (“goal, purpose, good”) for the Upaniṣad’s ātman (“Self”) in line with the dictum, “the goal is spoken of, but the self is not involved” (AN 3.72:6.3, AN 6.49:4.3). | For nipphadā (“accomplishment”), Pali normally uses the prefixed form abhinipphanna (“produced, manifested”) in this sense (MN 101:29.3, SN 47.10:6.11). And that is the form the root appears in the Upaniṣad, in the sense of the Self that “achieves” or “emerges into” in its own true form (8.12.2).

sn11.8:2.3.eng: A goal is splendid when accomplished—
sn11.8:2.3.comm: Pali texts read this as either nipphannasobhano attho (nominative singular) or nipphannasobhino atthā (dative singular). I propose both phrases occur as suits each speaker. The titan Verocana makes a simple statement (nominative), which the god Sakka improves by pointing to the cause (dative, following SN 11.4:7.3). This echoes the narrative form of the Upaniṣad, where Virocana is easily satisfied with surface teachings, taking only the body to be the Self. | The “splendid” or “shining” (sobhana) goal recalls the “highest light” (paraṃ jyotir) of the manifest Self.

sn11.8:2.4.eng: this is the word of Verocana!”
sn11.8:2.4.comm: Verocana asserts his authorship in imitation of the Upaniṣad, which repeatedly states, “this is the word of Prajāpati” (iti ha prajāpatir uvāca, 8.12.6).

sn11.8:3.3.eng: For the goal that’s splendid when accomplished,

sn11.8:3.4.eng: naught better than patience is found.”
sn11.8:3.4.comm: Indra and Virocana spent 32 years as Prajāpati’s students. Satisfied, Virocana left, while Indra stayed for a total of 101 years. Only then did Prajāpati reward his patience by revealing the deep truth.

sn11.8:4.1.comm: In the Upaniṣad, “all” qualifies that which is to be attained, namely all worlds and all desires (8.12.6). | Text has sattā (“beings”) and pāṇi (“creature”) for the Upaniṣad’s bhūta (8.11.1; also sarvabhūtāni at 8.15.1).

sn11.8:4.2.eng: as they deserve in each case.
sn11.8:4.2.comm: In other words, all creatures have individual and differing needs (see AN 4.32:2.4, DN 31:34.24). Verocana is arguing that the different needs of creatures can be satisfied if only they’d work hard enough, yoked in perpetuity like a beast of burden.

sn11.8:4.3.eng: But even so, harnessed work is the highest
sn11.8:4.3.comm: For saṁyoga, compare the Upaniṣad, “The life breath is yoked to this body, as a draft animal to a cart” (sa yathā prayogya ācaraṇe yukta evam evāyam asmiñ charīre prāṇo yuktaḥ, 8.12.3, translation Olivelle). This shows the original meaning of root yuj as “yoke” for beasts of burden, and hence the “work” those beasts do when “harnessed”.

sn11.8:4.4.eng: thing of value for all living creatures.
sn11.8:4.4.comm: When, in the Upaniṣad, Indra rejects lower teachings of the Self, he says he sees in it nothing “of value” (bhogya), corresponding to sambhoga here.

sn11.8:4.5.eng: A goal is splendid when accomplished—

sn11.8:4.6.eng: this is the word of Verocana!”

sn11.8:5.2.eng: as they deserve in each case.

sn11.8:5.3.eng: But rather than harnessed work being the highest
sn11.8:5.3.comm: I translate tveva as “but even so” when spoken by Verocana, and as “but rather than” when spoken by Sakka. I think Sakka’s response plays on the ambiguity of the term to reiterate his subtly different message. Verocana advocates for the virtue of hard work, Sakka for calm patience.

sn11.8:5.4.eng: thing of value for all living creatures,

sn11.8:5.5.eng: for the goal that’s splendid when accomplished,

sn11.8:5.6.eng: naught better than patience is found.”

sn11.9:1.2.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sambahulā isayo sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭīsu sammanti.
sn11.9:1.2.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, several seers who were ethical, of good character, settled in leaf huts in a wilderness region.
sn11.9:1.2.comm: “Seer” is isi (Sanskrit ṛṣi), for which the Proto-Dravidian root icai (“sing”) has been proposed. It was taken to mean that they had “seen” the Vedas (mantradraṣṭa) or directly “heard” them from Brahmā through divine inspiration, rather than “composing” them like ordinary authors. Here, however, the Buddha says they were “authors” (kattāro). The Buddha adopted isi in the sense “enlightened sage”. | A comparable encounter with seers is depicted at MN 93:18.2; see also the  description of ancient brahmins at DN 27:22.6.

sn11.9:1.3.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko ca devānamindo vepacitti ca asurindo yena te isayo sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu.
sn11.9:1.3.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, and Vepacitti, lord of titans, went to those seers.

sn11.9:1.4.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo paṭaliyo upāhanā ārohitvā khaggaṃ olaggetvā chattena dhāriyamānena aggadvārena assamaṃ pavisitvā te isayo sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme apabyāmato karitvā atikkami.
sn11.9:1.4.eng: Vepacitti put on his lined sandals, strapped on his sword, and, carrying a sunshade, entered the hermitage through the main gate. He walked right past those seers, keeping them at arm’s length.
sn11.9:1.4.comm: At Kv 12.8:4.3, it is said that a Buddhist would not treat a pagoda with disrespect by keeping it apabyāmato. The variant there is asabyākato, which is is similar to apasabyato at Ud 5.3:11.5, where it seems to mean “turning off to the left”. Here, however, I think it relates to the specific situation, corresponding to “downwind” in the next sentence. Vepacitti keeps the seers “at arm’s length” (apabyāmato) because they smell.

sn11.9:1.5.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo paṭaliyo upāhanā orohitvā khaggaṃ aññesaṃ datvā chattaṃ apanāmetvā dvāreneva assamaṃ pavisitvā te isayo sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme anuvātaṃ pañjaliko namassamāno aṭṭhāsi.
sn11.9:1.5.eng: Sakka took off his lined sandals, gave his sword to others, and, putting down his sunshade, entered the hermitage through the same gate. He stood downwind of those seers, revering them with joined palms.
sn11.9:1.5.comm: Each of these details corresponds with a training rule for monastics, who should not wear sandals or teach one wearing them; should not carry a sword or teach one carrying a sword; and should not carry a parasol or teach one carrying a parasol. There are exceptions for sandals and parasols for health. See too Thag 7.1 and SN 35.133.

sn11.9:1.6.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, te isayo sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsiṃsu:
sn11.9:1.6.eng: Then those seers addressed Sakka in verse:

sn11.9:2.1.comm: “Initiated” (dikkhita, Sanskrit dīkṣita) is the technical term for a priest who has been consecrated in preparation for a ritual.

sn11.9:2.2.eng: the odor of their bodies goes with the gale.

sn11.9:2.4.eng: The odor of the seers is unclean, king of gods.’
sn11.9:2.4.comm: One might expect the initiated to have a sweet smell (puṇyagandha; cf. sīlagandha at Dhp 55), and this is indeed the case normally (Gopatha Brāhmaṇa 1.2.2, Jaimini Gṛhyasūtra 1.18). Jain ascetics were known for body odors, as they did not bathe, but brahmins were fastidious about cleanliness. Humans generally are thought to be malodorous to the gods (DN 23:9.30), but the text specifies it is the odor of those long initiated.

sn11.9:3.2.eng: let the odor of their bodies go with the gale.

sn11.9:3.3.eng: We yearn for this odor, sirs,

sn11.9:3.4.eng: like a colorful crown of flowers.

sn11.9:3.5.eng: The gods don’t see it as repulsive.’”

sn2.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn2.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn2.1:1.3.pli: Atha kho kassapo devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho kassapo devaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn2.1:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Kassapa, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
sn2.1:1.3.comm: The commentary says that godlings (devaputta) are born “in the lap of the gods”, that is, not from a womb. Typically, in contrast with the “deities” (devatā), they are named individuals. The commentary also takes the term as gendered, with devaputta as “son of god” and devadhītā as “daughter of god”. But as the latter term is not attested in early Pali (or Sanskrit) we should probably take devaputta as gender neutral (like devatā). This is supported by pre-Buddhist Sanskrit, where we only find devaputra as an adjective, “the heaven and earth, whose children are gods”, where those children are “two young women, sisters” (Rig Veda 1.185.4). | Many of the Suttas in this chapter refer to Indra (i.e. Sakka) under different names. Indra was a son of the original Kassapa, so this may refer to Indra with the patronymic.

sn2.1:1.4.pli: “bhikkhuṃ bhagavā pakāsesi, no ca bhikkhuno anusāsan”ti.
sn2.1:1.4.eng: “The Buddha has revealed the mendicant, but not his instructions to a mendicant.”
sn2.1:1.4.comm: This is an unusual thing to say, as the Buddha obviously gave instructions for mendicants very often. It must have a specific context. The commentary supplies a context, but it relies on a later legend. | This suggests that the verse below, which is phrased as a direct exhortation to the mendicants, is to be read as Kassapa quoting the Buddha’s own words. However, no such verse is attributed to the Buddha in the Pali canon. At Thag 3.7:3.1 it is spoken by the mendicant Vāraṇa.

sn2.1:1.5.eng: “Well then, Kassapa, clarify this matter yourself.”

sn2.1:2.1.eng: “You should all train <j>to learn well-spoken words,
sn2.1:2.1.comm: I read sikkhetha as second person plural optative, and subhāsitassa (etc.) as dative (of purpose), although we would expect the āya form in this sense. The commentary glosses with third singular and accusative (subhāsitaṁ sikkheyya). Norman (Elders Verses I, note 239) suggests it may be locative.

sn2.1:2.3.eng: to sit alone in hidden places,

sn2.1:3.1.eng: That’s what the godling Kassapa said,

sn2.1:3.3.pli: Atha kho kassapo devaputto “samanuñño me satthā”ti bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn2.1:3.3.eng: Then Kassapa, knowing that the teacher approved, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.

sn2.10:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sūriyo devaputto rāhunā asurindena gahito hoti.
sn2.10:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Sun God had been seized by Rāhu, lord of titans.
sn2.10:1.2.comm: Suriya, the sun, is one of the most prominent deities of the Vedas, appearing under many names and aspects as both celestial body and deity.

sn2.10:1.3.pli: Atha kho sūriyo devaputto bhagavantaṃ anussaramāno tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.10:1.3.eng: Then the Sun God, recollecting the Buddha, at that time spoke this verse:

sn2.10:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sūriyaṃ devaputtaṃ ārabbha rāhuṃ asurindaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn2.10:3.1.eng: Then the Buddha addressed Rāhu in verse concerning the Sun God:

sn2.10:4.1.eng: “The Sun God has gone for refuge

sn2.10:4.2.eng: to the Realized One, the perfected one.

sn2.10:4.3.eng: The Buddhas have compassion for the world—

sn2.10:5.1.eng: He is a beacon in the darkness,
sn2.10:5.1.comm: The Buddha offers an extra verse to the Sun as compared to the Moon.

sn2.10:5.2.eng: the blazing sun, circle of awesome might.

sn2.10:5.3.eng: Rāhu, do not swallow him as he traverses the sky.
sn2.10:5.3.comm: The mention of “swallow” here confirms this detail of the mythology, which is also implied in the existence of a torture called “Rāhu’s mouth” (MN 13:14.3).

sn2.10:5.4.eng: Rāhu, release my offspring, the Sun!”
sn2.10:5.4.comm: The Buddha is the “kinsman of the sun” as he is a scion of the royal Solar Lineage traced back to the sun himself. Both Sun and Moon attended the Mahāsamayasutta (DN 20:14.3) where, according to the commentary, they became stream-enterers and hence the Buddha’s spiritual “sons”. Symbolically the Buddha, by enabling the Sun’s “release” from the “confined space”, becomes the father of light and wisdom.

sn2.10:6.1.pli: Atha kho rāhu asurindo sūriyaṃ devaputtaṃ muñcitvā taramānarūpo yena vepacitti asurindo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn2.10:6.1.eng: Then Rāhu, having released the Sun, rushed to see Vepacitti, lord of titans and stood to one side, shocked and awestruck.

sn2.10:6.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ kho rāhuṃ asurindaṃ vepacitti asurindo gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:

sn2.10:7.3.eng: and came here looking like you’re in shock:

sn2.10:7.4.eng: why do you stand there so scared?”

sn2.10:8.1.eng: “My head would have exploded in seven pieces,

sn2.10:8.2.eng: I would have found no joy in life,

sn2.10:8.3.eng: if, when enchanted by the Buddha’s verse,

sn2.10:8.4.eng: I had not released the Sun.”

sn2.11:1.2.pli: Atha kho candimaso devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn2.11:1.2.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Candimasa, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,
sn2.11:1.2.comm: Candimasa is another form of the shining “moon”, echoing Vedic candramasa (eg. Rig Veda 1.84.15, 10.64.3, Chāndogya Upaniṣad4.15.5, etc.). As often, there is no obvious link between the deity and the content of their verses.

sn2.11:1.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho candimaso devaputto bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.11:1.3.eng: and spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn2.11:2.2.eng: they will reach a safe place

sn2.11:3.1.eng: “Like fish when the net is cut,

sn2.11:3.2.eng: they will reach the far shore

sn2.11:3.4.comm: Rig Vedic raṇa usually means “joy, delight” (eg. 8.96.16, 10.104.7) or occasionally “battle, strife, conflict” (see MN 139). The commentary explains it here as “vice, defilement”. But compare Rig Veda 10.112.10, where Indra the “bounteous” (maghavan) is urged to “battle” and bestow a share of winnings on devotees. Likewise at 10.113.4 Indra’s successful “battle” is a prelude to releasing the waters. Then there is the oft-quoted line dhanañjayaṃ raṇe-raṇe (“winner of the stakes in every battle”, 1.74.3, 6.16.15). These suggest emendation to raṇañjaya (“victor in battle”), but this is not attested in Pali. On the other hand, the Chinese translation at SA 1303 seems to take raṇa in the sense of “delight” (喜樂). Also see the uddāna to Thag 1.50, vimalo ca raṇañjaho, which supports the commentarial sense “free of defilement”. On the whole, since the sense “strife” is clearly attested, and the development of Vedic “joy” to commentarial “defilement” is not well-attested, I am inclined to accept the sense “strife” in all cases, while suspecting that the original of raṇañjaha was raṇañjaya.

sn2.12:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho veṇḍu devaputto bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.12:1.1.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Vishnu spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
sn2.12:1.1.comm: Veṇhu (variant veṇḍu) is the Pali spelling of Sanskrit viṣṇu, who in Pali appears only here and at DN 20:14.1. He appears somewhat often in the Rig Veda, where he is an ally of Indra in his battle with the constrictor serpent (4.18.11, 6.20.2, 8.100.12). His name is explained as meaning “widespread” due to his role as the wide-stepping solar god who made three great strides over the earth, the midspace, and the heavens, opening up the broad expanse of the world. He also played a role in fertility (Rig Veda 7.36.9, 10.84.1). By the time of the Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa he was identified with the sacrifice (eg. 1.1.2.13), and was said to be a dwarf, perhaps as the shrunken sun of dusk (1.2.5.5). In one passage he is mystically identified with Indra as Maghavan (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 14.1.1.13). | Just as the previous chapter featured Indra under several names, the deities in the next few Suttas may also be names of Vishnu, although the identifications are weak.

sn2.12:2.1.comm: The common Pali terms manuja (“mankind”, “man”), manussa (“human”), and mānava (usually “(Vedic) student”, occasionally “son of man”) all have the same root sense, “child of Manu”. Vishnu himself was a child of Manu via his mother Ākūti, Manu’s daughter.

sn2.12:2.2.eng: who pay homage to the Holy One!

sn2.12:2.3.eng: They apply themselves to Gotama’s instructions,

sn2.12:3.1.eng: “Those who practice absorption <j>in accord with the training”,

sn2.12:3.3.eng: “in the way of teaching I’ve proclaimed,

sn2.12:3.4.eng: diligent while there is still time;

sn2.12:3.5.eng: they won’t fall under the sway of Death.”

sn2.13:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn2.13:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn2.13:1.3.pli: Atha kho dīghalaṭṭhi devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ veḷuvanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn2.13:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Dīghalaṭṭhi, lighting up the entire Bamboo Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,
sn2.13:1.3.comm: Dīghalaṭṭhi (“long stick”) is otherwise unknown. Following the previous Sutta, perhaps to be traced to Vishnu in the sense “wide success” (dīrghavyaṣṭi) in reference to his broad strides (cp. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 13.5.4.11).

sn2.13:1.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho dīghalaṭṭhi devaputto bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.13:1.4.eng: and spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn2.13:2.1.eng: “If a mendicant is a meditator, freed in mind,

sn2.13:2.2.eng: and if they desire the heart’s fulfillment—

sn2.13:2.3.eng: having known the arising and passing of the world,

sn2.13:2.4.eng: good-hearted, independent, that is their reward.”

sn2.14:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho nandano devaputto bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn2.14:1.1.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Nandana addressed the Buddha in verse:
sn2.14:1.1.comm: Elsewhere in Pali, Nandana is the name of the “Garden of Delight” in the heaven of the Thirty-Three. Nandana is also a name of Vishnu.

sn2.14:2.1.eng: “I ask you, Gotama, whose wisdom is vast,

sn2.14:2.2.eng: the Blessed One <j>of unhindered knowledge and vision.

sn2.14:2.3.eng: What sort do they call ethical?

sn2.14:2.4.eng: What sort do they call wise?

sn2.14:2.5.eng: What sort lives on after transcending suffering?

sn2.14:2.6.eng: What sort is worshipped by the deities?”

sn2.14:3.3.eng: who’s gotten rid of and given up all sorrows,

sn2.14:3.4.eng: with defilements ended, they bear their final body.

sn2.14:4.3.eng: That sort lives on after transcending suffering.

sn2.14:4.4.eng: That sort is worshipped by the deities.”

sn2.15:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho candano devaputto bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn2.15:1.1.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Candana addressed the Buddha in verse:
sn2.15:1.1.comm: Candana appears in MN 134:6.4 and SN 40.11:1.1, and together with Kāmaseṭṭha in DN 20:10.5 and DN 32:10.4. Candana means “sandalwood”, although the name of the god might also relate to its root “shining”. The name rhymes with the previous (nandana/candana).

sn2.15:2.1.comm: This question is found in two variants: “how do you cross the flood” (kathaṁsu tarati oghaṁ, Snp 1.10:8.1) and “who here crosses the flood” (ko sūdha tarati oghaṁ, Snp 1.9:23.1). The pattern seems to be that the question matches others in the same verse, so here it is “who”.

sn2.15:2.4.eng: does not sink in the deep?”

sn2.15:3.1.eng: “Someone who is always endowed with ethics,

sn2.15:3.4.eng: crosses the flood so hard to cross.

sn2.15:4.1.eng: Someone who desists from sensual perception,

sn2.15:4.2.eng: has moved past the fetter of form,

sn2.15:4.3.eng: and has finished with relishing and greed

sn2.15:4.4.eng: does not sink in the deep.”

sn2.16:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho vāsudatto devaputto bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn2.16:1.1.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Vāsudatta spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
sn2.16:1.1.comm: Vāsudatta (“son of Vasudatta”) is otherwise unknown, but Vāsu and Vāsudeva are both names of Vishnu.

sn2.16:2.2.eng: like their head was on fire,

sn2.16:3.2.eng: like their head was on fire,

sn2.17:1.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho subrahmā devaputto bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn2.17:1.1.eng: Standing to one side, the godling Subrahmā addressed the Buddha in verse:
sn2.17:1.1.comm: Probably not the same individual as the “independent divinity” Subrahmā (SN 6.6–8 and DN 20:20.1). In the Rig Veda, subrahma meant “good sacred formulation” (Rig Veda 7.16.2, 10.47.3, 10.62.4)

sn2.17:2.5.eng: If there is a state free of anxiety,

sn2.17:3.1.comm: PTS reads bojjhaṅgatapasā; Yogācārabhūmi Śarīrārthagāthā 5.2 hasjñānatapaso; SA 596 seems to pass over bojjha; while SA2 181 has 智慧者, “wise one”. I follow Bodhi in accepting the MS reading, nāññatra bojjhā tapasā.

sn2.17:3.2.eng: not without restraining the sense faculties,

sn2.17:3.3.eng: not without letting go of everything,

sn2.17:3.4.eng: do I see safety for living creatures.”

sn2.17:4.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said. …
sn2.17:4.1.comm: This prose fragment is unusual here. Such endings are normally abbreviated in the Pali, although they are retained in the Chinese.
